newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU says neutral on Lufthansa part-sale.
newsitem.headline: EU says neutral on Lufthansa part-sale.

text.p: The European Commission said on Thursday it was neutral on German government plans to sell the remainder of the airline Deutsche Lufthansa AG, adding that any sell-off should not favour German buyers ahead of other EU investors.

European Transport Commissioner Neil Kinnock wrote to German Transport Minister Matthias Wissmann earlier this week in reply to informal soundings from Bonn on what it thought of German government plans to sell off its remaining 36 percent holding in the airline.
"The German government is not obliged to inform us of its intentions...The Commissioner, in that spirit, has written a letter back," spokeswoman Sarah Lambert told a news conference,
"This, of course, in no way prejudges (Commission views on the legality of) an eventual privatisation," she added
Kinnock expressed neutrality about whether the possible sale should go ahead albeit with the added proviso that a sell-off should treat all EU investors equally.

While the EU executive is legally bound to be neutral on the question of private versus public ownership of companies, it has favoured private-sector-style restructuring of the bloc's aviation sector.

The reference to non-discrimination is important in that EU rules on airline ownership require EU-based carriers to be at least 51-percent-owned by EU shareholders, a Commission official later told reporters.
If Bonn were to sell its remaining stake in the airline it might have to withhold or buy back some shares to ensure Lufthansa met these ownwership rules, the official said.

In addition, if Bonn applied the 51 percent figure to the number of German-held shares in Lufthansa rather than EU-held ones, any buyback plan would have to treat German and other EU investors equally, the official added.
